Hi, I think I've bumped into a bug very similar to #20232: sometimes, the last element of the original stream gets skipped. I'll try to get an isolated reproduction, but here's a bit of guesswork so far:

Looking at the fix and the code, it would seem as if there was a race condition between `onTimer` and `onStreamFinish` — note that according to the [GraphStageLogic documentation](https://doc.akka.io/japi/akka/current/akka/stream/stage/GraphStageLogic.html), `onTimer` is not thread safe with regard to the internal state  (emphasis is mine):

>  * Possible mutable state, accessible from the `InHandler` and `OutHandler` callbacks, **but not from anywhere else (as such access _would not be thread-safe_)**
.groupedWithin can omit the last element from the source

```
    scheduler.schedule(Duration.ofSeconds(1),
                       Duration.ofSeconds(1),
                       getSelf(),
                       MetricsLoggingTick.getInstance(),
                       getContext().getSystem()
                         .getDispatcher(),
                       ActorRef.noSender());
```
There are some situations I would like to write 
```
    scheduler.schedule(Duration.ofSeconds(1),
                       Duration.ofSeconds(1),
                       getSelf(),
                       () -> generateNewMessage() ,//the generator
                       getContext().getSystem()
                         .getDispatcher(),
                       ActorRef.noSender());
```
add an overloaded method with messageGenerator parameter to `Scheduler#schedule`
like `dropNew` and `dropOld`,the default implementation seems like `dropNew` by default.

```
      .match(interestedEventClazz,
             event -> handleEvent(event))
      .matchEquals(MetricsLoggingTick.getInstance(),

```
I would more like to write

```
    return receiveBuilder()
      .match(interestedEventClazz,
             event -> handleEvent(event))
      .matchEquals(MetricsLoggingTick.getInstance(),
                   () -> doLogging())
```

I believe `Source. unfoldResourceAsync` does not call its `close` function when the `read` function returns a failed future. I read the use of `Source. unfoldResourceAsync` as a streams version of a `try`/`finally` block.

What is the view here on whether the `close` function should always be called, regardless of failure given that `create` was performed with success?
Source. unfoldResourceAsync should call close on read failure

As it is now the stream attribute `Name`'s value is URL encoded in the `name` factory method which makes it less usable for human eyes when used in graph printouts or monitoring tools.

https://github.com/akka/akka/blob/v2.5.17/akka-stream/src/main/scala/akka/stream/Attributes.scala#L340

The encoded name is required when it is used as part of an actor path. The un-encoded name should be kept around for all other use.

The project uses actor based distributed pub-sub to handle topics published and subscribed. Due to the massive workflow of the project uses akka's actor modelling. Extending of the akka cluster-tools library for topics pub-sub, I am facing the following issues from the library. 
Just for the demonstration of the issue. I have reproduced the same issue with the sample test code from the documentation.

#####  Code
I was running the following snippet of code referred from the documentation. 

```java
public class DistributedPubSubExample extends AbstractActor {

    LoggingAdapter log = Logging.getLogger(getContext().system(), this);

    /**
     * DistributedPubSubExample.
     */
    public DistributedPubSubExample() {
        ActorRef mediator =
                DistributedPubSub.get(getContext().system()).mediator();
        mediator.tell(new DistributedPubSubMediator.Subscribe("content", getSelf()),
                getSelf());
    }

    @Override
    public Receive createReceive() {
        return receiveBuilder()
                .match(String.class, msg ->
                        log.info("Got: {}", msg))
                .match(DistributedPubSubMediator.SubscribeAck.class, msg ->
                        log.info("subscribed"))
                .build();
    }
}
```
----

#####  Issue
At the time of compiling, I am getting the following error. 

```
[error] /home/arun/Developer/DistributedPubSub/src/main/java/DistributedPubSubExample.java:17:1: reference to get is ambiguous
[error]   both method get(akka.actor.ActorSystem) in akka.cluster.pubsub.DistributedPubSub and method get(akka.actor.ActorSystem) in akka.cluster.pubsub.DistributedPubSub match
[error]                 DistributedPubSub.get(getContext().system()).mediator();
[error] (Compile / compileIncremental) javac returned non-zero exit code
[error] Total time: 5 s, completed 1 Nov 2018, 11:22:03
```
-----
##### Setup
- Java 8/11 ( Tried with both the version of JVM)
- Akka 2.5.17 (same version for akka-cluster-tools) 
- scala version 2.12.7
- Build tool : sbt 1.2.6

##### Notes
- I have tried compiling the code with JRE 11 as well as JRE 1.8, the issue remains the same.
DistributedPubSub -  reference to get is ambiguous

There's a broken link to the Lagom framework here in the docs: https://doc.akka.io/docs/akka/current/persistence.html?language=scala#scaling-out

The correct URL is: https://www.lagomframework.com/
Broken link to the Lagom framework website
Save EntityStarted when StartEntity requested via remembered entities

The zipLatest stage (https://doc.akka.io/docs/akka/snapshot/stream/operators/Source-or-Flow/zipLatest.html) currently completes when any of the upstream streams complete.

This can make sense, but in other cases it can be more useful to keep repeating the last element of any closed stream, and only complete the stage it when all incoming streams have completed.

It might make sense to add a parameter for this.

There was a recent feature request over in akka-http, https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/2259, which asked for `SO_REUSEPORT` support.

It seems starting from Java 9 this socket option is supported:

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/net/StandardSocketOptions.html
Support SO_REUSEPORT as socket options in Akka IO on Java 9+

Should enable `scalafix` on Akka project.
At least for `unused import`s ,that's very annoying.
